text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

This IRM provides instructions for administrative issues in ﬁeld and headquarters locations performed by the Senior Commissioner’s Representative (SCR) and their Administrative Officers (AOs) resulting from the Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998. The SCR has been in existence since 2001, but has relied on memoranda and general practice as authorities and guidance. This IRM codiﬁed these

) This IRM provides instructions for administrative issues in ﬁeld and headquarters locations by the Senior Commissioner’s Representative (SCR) and their Administrative Officers from the Restructuring and Reform Act of

) Links updated. (
) Editorial changes for consistency.

The Senior Commissioner’s Representatives, Administrative Officers, Commissioner’s Representatives (CRs), and Alternate Commissioner’s Representatives (ACRs), and all employees affected by these policies.

Senior Commissioner’s Representatives Roles in Management of IRS Field and Headquarters Offices 1.4.12 page
Headquarters Offices

) Purpose: a. This IRM centrally locates the requirements for Senior Commissioner’s Representatives (SCRs) responsible for administrative operations at a cross-functional level, serving all business units at ﬁeld and offices. The program operations include, but are not limited to, general work environment, local labor management relations, and The SCRs are responsible for overseeing Servicewide program opera- tions generally covering a multi-state area of the United States. The of the SCR is responsible for incident and emergency management; relations; external representation; issue resolution; Commissioner and community or customer support. b. The SCR team includes AOs, CRs and ACRs supporting IRS Posts of Duty (POD), and administrative support staff. c. The geographic map of SCR areas is shown at Senior Commissioner’s Representative - Home (irsnet.gov). (

) Audience. These procedures provide policy, guidance, and instructions to employees in headquarters and ﬁeld offices serviced by: • SCR-CO Director and support staff; • SCRs; • Administrative Officers (AOs); • Commissioner’s Representatives (CRs); • Alternate Commissioner’s Representatives (ACRs); • Campus Site Coordinators for incident and emergency related • Partner Service Providers such as HCO, IT, and FMSS. (
) Policy Owner. The policy owner of this IRM is the Deputy Chief of Staff of Commissioner’s Office (C:C
:DC
) Program Owner. The program owner is the Director, Senior Representatives and Continuity Operations. (
) Stakeholders. All audience listed above plus external agencies and boards (such as Federal Executive Board). (
) As part of the Restructuring and Reform Act of

, SCRs and AOs were assigned to serve as the Head of Office in local cross-functional labor matters and IRS interests in interagency affairs as well as coordinate local ministrative programs in headquarters and ﬁeld offices. No changes to SCR roles and responsibilities were proposed in the Taxpayer First Act of
) The list of roles was ﬁrst described in a memorandum from the Deputy missioner of Internal Revenue, entitled Role of the Senior Commissioner’s Representatives dated November
, and included Office Closing authority. This memo speciﬁed that the SCRs have the right to delegate authorities and decisions across business units. (
) A second memorandum from the Deputy Commissioner for Operations Support, entitled Senior Commissioner Representatives dated October
, speciﬁed that the SCRs are to be the Administrative Heads of Office emergency response and other cross-functional responsibilities, with the aim Internal Revenue Manual

state area of the United States. ) Deputy Business Continuity Operations Officer is the executive with oversight over all Incident Management and Continuity Functions: a. Designated as the IRS Continuity Coordinator; b. Chair of incident management and/or continuity of operations Steering Committees; c. Ensures compliance with all applicable laws, guidance, and related to incident management; d. Approves ﬁnal Incident Management Team (IMT) After-Action Reports; e. Ultimately responsible for compliance of audits. (

) Director, Senior Commissioner’s Representatives and Continuity of erations is the program manager with oversight over Senior Representatives, Field Operations, and Continuity of Operations: a. Coordinates various cross functional activities; b. Acts as Area Incident Commander (Ensures compliance with all appli- cable laws, guidance, and procedures; ensures participants in response are trained; and ensures completion of After-Action Report IMT). (

) Field Operations Manager is responsible for SCR Field Operations, cross-area issues and incidents: a. Is the contact for issues with other service provider Business Units b. Develops uniform policies for Servicewide implementation of Field tions activities; c. Develops standards and training for SCRs and AOs. (

) Senior Commissioner’s Representatives are responsible for operations at a cross-functional level: a. Serve all business units at ﬁeld and headquarters offices; b. Program operations including but not limited to general work environ- ment, local labor management relations, and emergency related (

reducing administrative burden. This enables the IRS to ensure employee safety, protect Service property, and provide continuity of operations.
Senior Commissioner’s Representatives Roles in Management of IRS Field and Headquarters Offices 1.4.12 page 3

a. To support activities and services in IRS offices in their designated Commissioner’s Representative (SCR) geographic area of coverage; b. Is the SCR’s representative for identifying, coordinating, and building or geographic area-wide cross-functional issues; c. Serves as the primary coordinator for cross-functional administrative support activities and initiatives of functional service providers. (
) Commissioner’s Representatives: a. Local to a POD; b. Collateral duty to regular assignments; c. Act as Incident Commander until the SCR takes control. (

) SCR Field Operations maintain and report on the program goals and described below. Summaries of these counts are reported quarterly to the Director SCR-CO and the Chief, Business Continuity Operations Officer. (
) Quarterly reports measuring the effectiveness of program responsibilities collected on average customer satisfaction scores and rates generated by surveys at SCR related meetings and programs. (
) Engagement with customers is measured by counting the number of and attendees: a. Horizontal Communication Meeting attendance; b. Timely resolution of LR/Formal Article
cases; c. Leadership coordination activities per event; d. Cross Functional coordination activities per event. (
) Head of Office Responsibilities is measured by counts of: a. Formal Labor Relations - Articles
and
; b. Formal Labor Relations - All other (excluding Articles
and

); c. Formal Labor Relations - Arbitration/Impasse; d. Informal Labor Relations; e. Incident Management - Major events; f. Incident Management - Other events; g. Business Continuity/Incident Planning Support; h. National Labor Committee meetings; i. Federal Executive Board/Federal Executive Association Meetings; (
) Service Provider Responsibilities are measured by counts of: a. FMSS Support activities; b. HCO Support activities; c. IT Support activities; (

1.4 Resource Guide for Managers

) Business Unit - Single unit of organization within IRS centered around speciﬁc processes or types of taxpayers. Chiefs/Commissioners of business units report to one of the Deputy Commissioners or directly to the Commis- sioner. (
) Continuity - Synonymous with Business Resumption. This is covered by
Overview of Continuity Planning and IRM
Incident Plan. (
) Cross-functional issue - Any event or action which involves more than one Business Unit (BU). (
) Emergency Operations Center - The central command and control facility where the IMT meets to manage and/or coordinate response and recovery erations. May be physical or virtual. (

) Emergency Situation - Any potential endangerment of IRS employees or ruption to IRS processes, whether during working hours or directly affecting IRS employees or facilities. OEP guidelines are to be followed in an emergency situation. (
) Incident - An occurrence or event, natural or man-made, that requires a response to protect life or property. (
) Incident Commander - Individual directly responsible for management of incident. (
) Incident Management Plan - Plan that focuses on the command and coordination & communications activities, and management of a disruption any IRS site. See IRM
Incident Management Plan. (
) Office Closure - Responsibility of the SCRs and follows IRM
Emergency Dismissals and Office Closures. This involves granting tive Leave which is delegated solely to the SCRs by IRM
Administrative Leave. for the employee’s Post of Duty (Facility where IRS employees are assigned to work). Telework does not change an employee’s Post of Duty. (

) Senior Commissioner’s Representatives - The SCRs serve as the Head Office in local cross-functional labor relations matters and IRS interests in agency affairs as well as coordinate local administrative programs. SCRs direct activities in critical emergencies service-wide ensuring business ity plans are in place and followed during incidents.. (

) Service Provider Business Unit - Other Business Units in the Deputy missioner Operations Support such as Human Capital Office (HCO), Management Security Services (FMSS), Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion and Information Technology (IT), with which Field Operations works to administrative issues. (
) The following acronyms are used throughout this document: Acronym Name ACR Alternate Commissioner’s Representative Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H

) The SCR is the Administrative Head of Office in their geographic area for purposes of achieving cooperation, coordination, and administration of the of Agency’s cross-functional programs and processes. This allows functional ecutives and managers to devote full attention to their program areas. The SCR has distinct responsibilities in emergency management, labor relations, and community building. (

) For employees in Field Office/Headquarters PODs, SCR duties include: a. Leading emergency incident efforts at IRS offices with authority to offices, as necessary, based on weather or emergency situations; b. Serving as Designated Official (DO) and Chair of the Facility Security Committee (FSC) when the IRS is the lead agency and SCR or higher graded AO is on-site; c. Leading local modiﬁed national bargaining, including hearing mass institutional grievances from local union chapters and representing arbitration; d. Providing leadership in delivering IRS’ Occupational Health & Safety Program, within their jurisdiction; e. Representing IRS with interagency groups such as the local Federal Executive Board (FEB) and Federal Executive Association (FEA); f. Exercising ﬁnal decision-making authority on unresolved local, cross- functional issues; g. Providing liaison for IRS Commissioner and dignitary visits and virtual town halls;
1.4.12.1.7 (07-20-2022) Related Resources
(07-20-2022) Administrative Head of Office

site; c. Leading local modiﬁed national bargaining, including hearing mass institutional grievances from local union chapters and representing arbitration; d. Representatives Roles in Management and Headquarters Offices

h. Facilitating and coordinating services for cross-functional work-life in local offices; i. Appointing, training, and providing leadership and guidance to CRs ACRs located on-site in each IRS office. (
) For employees on Home as POD (H
), Full Time Telework, and Telework, SCRs are responsible for: a. Emergency notiﬁcation (IRM
Emergency Notiﬁcation System (A
oc)); b. Employee accountability for both non-IMT and IMT situations. (
) For Campus locations, SCRs assume responsibility for large-scale (
) Other issues should be addressed by the responsible manager and Unit (such as FMSS and EDI). (

) The SCR leads the IRS emergency response to incidents affecting ﬁeld and employees. Incidents may include inclement weather; power outages, natural or human-made disasters. During an incident, the SCR evaluates health, safety, and security conditions to determine whether an office should closed and for what duration. (

) The SCR is the designated Incident Commander (IC) for all emergency affecting business operations, and as such has the responsibility for ing full or partial office closures and length of closures as well as being the ﬁnal decision maker and directing all national and local activities related to emergency event. The SCR/IC leads and directs the response, stabilization, devolution, and reconstitution activities through the Incident Management (IMT) for all IRS emergency events and resumption activities. The SCR/IC directs all response and resumption activities through a suite of plans that include the Occupant Emergency Plan (OEP), Incident Management Plan (IMP), Business Unit Continuity Plans (CPs), and Information Systems gency Plan (ISCP). (

) The IC acts on behalf of the Commissioner/Deputy Commissioners in the leadership of an emergency event. The role of IC reduces the burden on business units, allowing them to focus on their business unit resumption business continuity responsibilities. The IC ensures: a. Restoration and resumption of normal business operations; b. Damage assessment and facility readiness; c. Documentation of events including writing an After Action Report if required; d. Employee accountability; e. Internal and external communications; f. Brieﬁngs to Senior Executive Team (SET), Department of the Treasury, Office of Personnel Management, and other government officials as necessary. (

) In addition to being IC in their own areas, the SCR is available to serve in roles for other SCR areas and campuses for large scale incidents. AOs support the IC in a variety of roles and are available to support other SCR areas as needed. Internal Revenue Manual

Restoration and resumption of normal business operations; Damage assessment and facility readiness; Documentation of events including writing an After Action Report if required; Employee accountability; Internal and external communications; Brieﬁngs to Senior Executive Team (SET), Department of the Office of Personnel Management, and other government officials as necessary.
Resource Guide for (

) In an office with no on-site SCR, the initial IC is the CR or ACR. The IC transitions to the SCR as soon as the SCR can take control of the event. some instances, the SCR may not arrive on site but will take command of incident remotely. (
) Delegation Order
(formerly DO-
), IRM

Temporary Office Closures Due to Inclement Weather, Imminent Health and Safety Issues, or Decisions Other Emergency Situations authorizes the SCRs to: a. Evacuate employees; b. Close offices due to inclement weather, imminent health and safety issues, or other emergencies; c. Dismiss employees from duty without charge to leave or loss of pay short periods in accordance with IRM
Temporary Office Closures Due to Inclement Weather, Imminent Health and Safety or Other Emergency Situations. (

) During an emergency event, the SCR assesses information from the CR, AO, and other sources as appropriate. Based on this information, the SCR may decide to close, delay opening, or dismiss employees early. (

) Reasons for closures include: a. Inclement weather conditions (snow/ice, hurricanes, etc.); b. Building imminent health and safety issues (hazardous material (HAZMAT), air quality, infectious disease, etc.), and perimeter security conditions (protests, demonstrations, etc.); c. Other facility conditions (ﬂooding, no electricity, no heat/air etc.) or; d. State and/or local officials request the people not travel and/or other community impact (major mass transit disruptions, local infrastructure issues, etc.). Note: When events also affect local Campus operations and/or nearby federal agencies, the SCR consults with the Campus SCR, FEBs, and/or other agency leadership for consistency in decision-making. In the National Region, the Office of Personnel Management makes office closing affecting all federal offices. (

) The SCR ensures timely decisions and prompt communications to all employees, emergency stakeholders, and NTEU when making an decision. a. Under the direction of the SCR, the AO works with CRs, Operations Support service providers, National Treasury Employees Union and other agencies during emergency management activities; b. The AO will prepare communications for employees, remote and leadership through the current IRS notiﬁcation systems. This may include A
oc, the IRS Emergency Hotline, or other systems as The AO will also prepare the SAMC report. (
) See IRS Dismissal and Closure Procedures https://irssource.web.irs.gov/ Linked%
Documents%
Library/IRS-Dismissal-Closure-Procedures.pdf further guidance.

Senior Commissioner’s Representatives Roles in Management of IRS Field and Headquarters Offices 1.4.12 page 9
Representatives Roles in Management and Headquarters Offices
page (

) The Facility Security Committee (FSC) is the committee responsible for ad- dressing facility-speciﬁc security issues and approving the implementation of protective measures and practices. For facilities with two or more federal tenants with funding authority, an FSC will be established to make security decisions for the facility. At those federal facilities where IRS is the primary lead agency as determined by the Interagency Security Committee the highest ranking IRS official at the site, typically the SCR, higher graded or the SCR designee, will serve as the DO. (

) The DO is responsible for the development of the building OEP and is the Chair of the FSC. The DO directs emergency activities (evacuations, shelter-in-place, etc.) for that facility and shares communications with other agency heads regarding emergency management/ FSC related activities. DO will ensure a current, updated OEP is in place: a. When the IRS holds the DO position, the DO will work with Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS) in the development of the building OEP and in the OEP training for all building occupants; b. The FSC member (SCR, higher graded AO or designee) will consult FMSS regarding all security proposals prior to voting. (

) Documents should be maintained by FSCs for ISC requirements and audit purposes: a. SCRs should maintain records such as minutes of meetings, voting decisions, and ISC training certiﬁcates on SCR-CO Shar
oint site; b. The Nationwide Central Repository is maintained by FMSS and will house the essential documentation of the FSC. All queries should be directed to the local SCR. (
) Frequency of meetings should be in accordance with Interagency Security Committee guidelines. (
) The SCR, in cooperation with FMSS and Continuity of Operations, in exercises and training activities to ensure agency readiness in the event large-scale emergency. (
) Each SCR and AO must complete these courses to participate in the FSCs: a. IS-

Course Schedule. Participates in personnel preparedness in the event of a local emergency imminent safety/health risk. These exercises and training activities include: a. Integrated Functional Exercises (IFE): SCRs and Continuity of collaborate in conducting IFEs, including communications and arrangements; b. Incident Management Workshop for IMT readiness: SCRs appoint members including command staff and general staff and ensure they derstand their roles, including possible deployment at any time. AOs conduct annual calling tree exercises for all IMTs and Local Continuity Representatives (LCRs) to ensure current contact c. OEP Exercises and Drills: FMSS is responsible to ensure evacuation SIP drills are scheduled and conducted and ensures the OEP is populated with the appropriate number of team members. When necessary, the SCR has the management authority to garner business unit resources for cross-functional activities, which include recruiting team members. FMSS has responsibility for creating, maintaining, and updating OEPs. See IRM

, Occupant Emergency Planning more information.; d. Other trainings opportunities as they occur. All training and exercises may be conducted either in person or virtually. Attendees will receive credit in Integrated Talent Management (ITM): a. Integrated Functional Exercise (face-to-face) -

page a. SCRs do not have primary responsibility in responding to or facilitating Reasonable Accommodations, however, SCRs should be aware during any emergency related event; b. See IRM
Providing Reasonable Accommodation for Individuals with Disabilities. (
) Contractors with staff-like access: a. See IRM

Personnel Security, Contractor Investigations for about employee-like issues and procurement responsibilities. Examples of contractors with staff-like access include mail room employees full time at a POD, or IT computer specialists. The responsibility for the safety and security of these contractors are divided between the and their contracting organization. (

) The SCR is the lead management official in a geographic area responsible bargaining with NTEU as well as handling cross-functional institutional griev- ances and unfair labor practice (ULP) ﬁlings. The SCR is involved in: a. Grievances; b. Mandatory meetings; c. Modiﬁed National Bargaining. (

) The National Agreement (NA) directs local NTEU to ﬁle mass grievances a business unit executive with employees covered by the grievance. Mass grievances related to cross-functional (more than one business unit) matters are usually delegated by the executive to the SCR to handle the grievance including serving as the decision maker for arbitration settlement The SCR works with Labor Relations and the program owner, reviews the NTEU position and issues decision and implementation instructions. (

) Grievance types: a. Mass grievances: A business unit executive may designate the SCR to handle mass grievances based on cross-functional issues; b. Institutional grievances: A grievance that involves more than one in a particular SCR area will be ﬁled with the SCR with jurisdiction over the area within which the grievance arose. (

) Management and NTEU recognize that the entrance into formal agreement with each other is an act of joint participation and the success of a labor- management relationship is further assured if a forum is available and used communicate with each other. The NA provides for local committees for the purpose of: a. Building strong relationships between key leaders of each party; b. Exchanging information and receiving pre-decisional input; c. Discussing matters of concern in the broad areas of personnel policies, practices, and working conditions and; d. Attempting to resolve problems informally in lieu of more protracted costly negotiations or grievance proceedings. Internal Revenue Manual

1.4 Resource Guide for Managers
The SCR is the designated management leader to oversee NA-mandated local committees. The SCR duties include:
a. Chairing or co

chairing (with NTEU) the required meetings; b. Serving as the management spokesperson or ensuring the appropriate business unit representative is available to address the issues raised; c. Ensuring all contractual provisions related to the committees are executed; and d. Elevating appropriate issues from the local committees to Headquarters BU level and HCO, Office of HR Operations, Labor Relations Strategy Negotiations (LRSN).
Note: At local discretion and by mutual agreement, one or more of these may be merged with another.

a. Labor-Management Relations Committee (LMRC): The SCR provides management leadership and oversight for the LMRC, obtains tion by subject matter experts and business unit representatives, approves agenda items, coordinates with the LRSN, ensures of outstanding agenda items, and updates committee members; b. Diversity and EEO Advisory Committee (DEEOAC): The SCR provides management oversight and leadership to the committee, solicits unit members, appoints management committee members, and issues local communications; c. Safety Advisory Committee (SAC): The SCR provides management oversight and leadership to the committee, solicits business unit members, appoints management committee members, and reviews requests to issue local communications/programs. ) The SCR is the Head of Office and lead management official in their geo- graphic area engaged with local executives, dignitaries, and points-of-contact for dignitary visits. The SCR leads local logistical arrangements working directly with contacts on the Commissioner’s Chief of Staff; Deputy Commis- sioner Services & Enforcement/Deputy Commissioner Operations Support (DCOS/DCSE) staff; Treasury Secretary staff; IRS Oversight Board Senators and Representatives (Congress); and foreign tax officials. (

) The SCR is responsible for the local coordination and communications for Commissioner/Deputy Commissioner visits to any PODs in the SCR’s geo- graphical area. The SCR works with the Office of the Commissioner to plan these visits. The SCR organizes all logistics, to include: a. Scheduling meetings and town halls with employees, managers, execu- tives and NTEU; b. Organizing focus groups; c. Preparing a brieﬁng document; d. Arranging tours; e. Assisting business units with coordinating special presentations; f. Developing the itinerary; g. Issuing all-employee communications; and h. Escorting the Commissioner/Deputy Commissioners during their visit. Internal Revenue Manual

Resource Guide for agreement of the CR’s business unit (next level approval). There are no speciﬁc terms of assignment as CR, but all on-site business units should in this collateral responsibility. (
) Due to the number of PODs in a geographical SCR area, the AO is the CRs primary liaison with the SCR. When an AO is on-site, the SCR may the AO as the CR. (

) CRs are responsible for protecting the safety and security of employees in their POD. Their main function is emergency management. Using the OEP they respond to, and manage, incidents until the SCR can take command. (

) CRs also serve a communications role by relaying information to the SCR (typically through the AO) regarding local issues such as inclement weather power outages to ensure appropriate action can be taken. (

) CRs should never risk injury or death as part of their duties. For example, sponding to intrusion alarms is the responsibility of either the Federal Protective Service or local law enforcement, NOT the CR. If there is any un- certainty the CR should contact the SCR. (

) The CR is the initial Incident Commander (IC) and local point of contact for emergencies that affect their assigned office. These incidents can include inclement weather, imminent threats to employee safety, health, and security, or adverse impact to the facility (power outage, ﬂoods, ﬁre, etc.). As the IC, the CR: a. Provides leadership in an emergency; b. Makes decisions that ensure employee safety using the OEP; c. Contacts the SCR for guidance as soon as feasible; d. Transitions the IC role to the SCR as soon as the SCR can take of the incident. Note: In some instances, the SCR may not arrive on site but will take command an incident remotely. (

) The CR is responsible for advising the SCR or AO when local conditions affect IRS office operating status. These conditions can include severe weather, power or HVAC outages, and activity at or near the POD (protests, criminal activity). Typically, the CR is the initial source of information about incidents affecting their POD. Timely, thorough, and accurate input from the is critical. (

) For weather related issues, the CR may provide information on local road conditions, and operating status of other government offices. The CR uses a variety of resources including local media, weather-related web sites, contacts at nearby federal agencies, and recommendations from local FEBs available). (
) The CR is expected to consult with the SCR on all incidents. However, per Delegation Order

, if imminent health and safety issues exist at their assigned POD, the CR has the authority to evacuate employees, and if necessary, close the office not to exceed one workday, in accordance with plicable statutes, executive orders, regulations, and policies.

) An OEP provides emergency procedures for the protection of life and in a speciﬁc POD. It includes emergency contacts and lists all POD employees during an emergency. An OEP tells what to do in a ﬁre, a weather emergency, a HAZMAT event, a bomb threat, active and other emergencies that might occur. (
) In an incident, the CR is responsible for activating the OEP. The CR also activates the OEP when leading drills at their POD, including evacuation shelter in place drills. (
) The CR must maintain a copy of the OEP for their POD and notify FMSS OEP program owner) and the AO when there are changes in contact tion. (
) FMSS has responsibility for creating, maintaining, and updating OEPs. IRM
